Class TextReader

java.lang.Object
  uk.ac.macaulay.util.TextReader

public class TextReader
extends java.lang.Object

A tool to assist with reading text files.

Author:
Gary Polhill

readExactString

public boolean readExactString(java.lang.String str,
                               boolean ignoreCase,
                               boolean ignoreLeadingSpace)
                        throws java.io.IOException
Read the exact string given in the str argument, with options to ignore case and ignore leading whitespace. The other readExactString() methods all call this one. If ignoreLeadingSpace is true, then this method will fail if str begins with any whitespace characters.

Parameters:
str - The string to read (should not have whitespace if ignoreLeadingSpace is true
ignoreCase - true if the string is not case sensitive
ignoreLeadingSpace - true if any leading whitespace should be ignored
Returns:
true if the string was read successfully
Throws:
java.io.IOException

readInt

public int readInt()
            throws java.io.IOException

Read an integer. On failure to do so, a FileFormatException is thrown. When reading from a file where you don't know how many integers you are going to read, the following idiom could be used:

  TextReader reader;

  while(!reader.eof()) {
    try {
      int number = reader.readInt();

    }
    catch(NumberFormatException e) {
      if(!reader.eof()) throw e;
    }
  }

Returns:
The integer read
Throws:
java.io.IOException

                                 java.util.EnumSet<TextReader.Comment> comments)
                          throws java.io.IOException

Returns:

Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
readWord(boolean,EnumSet,char)

readWord

public java.lang.String readWord(boolean ignoreLeadingSpace,
                                 java.util.EnumSet<TextReader.Comment> comments,
                                 char delimiter)
                          throws java.io.IOException

Read a word, allowing comments, optionally ignoring leading whitespace, and allowing the word to be terminated by a character other than space. If ignoreLeadingSpace is true, this method will throw away characters up to the first non-whitespace character (comments are also thrown away), then read into the returned value until the delimiter character is reached. All the other readWord(), readExactNumber(), and readInt(), readLong(), readFloat() and readDouble() methods call this one, with a space as the delimiter.

The return value will be the empty String ("") if the end of the file was reached without reading anything. To check, do something like this:

  TextReader reader;

  String word = readWord(); // Calls this method
  if(word.length() == 0) {
    // whatever
  }

Or if you're paranoid or want to future-proof this method:

  if(word == null || word.length() == 0) {

Parameters:
ignoreLeadingSpace -
comments -
delimiter - Character to stop reading the word (not included in the return value, and thrown away). If a space (' ', 0x32), then any whitespace character will stop the word.
Returns:
The word read
Throws:
java.io.IOException

readQuotedString

                                         char endQuote)
                                  throws java.io.IOException

See Also:
readQuotedString(EnumSet,char,char)

readQuotedString

public java.lang.String readQuotedString(java.util.EnumSet<TextReader.Comment> comments,
                                         char startQuote,
                                         char endQuote)
                                  throws java.io.IOException
Read a string enclosed by two characters, one at the start, one at the end, allowing comments. This method calls readWord(boolean,EnumSet,char) to read up to and including the startQuote character, ignoring any leading space and any comments. The word read by that call is expected to have zero length. (That is, a FileFormatException is thrown if the next non-whitespace non-comment character in the buffer isn't startQuote.) All characters up to, but not including endQuote are then read in to the returned value. No comments are allowed in the quoted string. The endQuote character is read from the buffer, but thrown away.

Parameters:
comments - Comments that may appear before the quoted string
startQuote - The character denoting the start of the quoted string
endQuote - The character denoting the end of the quoted string
Returns:
The string inside the quoted string
Throws:
java.io.IOException

readLine

public java.lang.String readLine()
                          throws java.io.IOException
Read a line from the buffer. Strictly, this method reads from the current point in the buffer to the line-termination character(s). It is not necessarily the case that the last character read by the buffer was a line-terminator. If such is indeed not the case, then the returned value will not be an entire line.

Returns:
The line read (not including line-termination characters)
Throws:
java.io.IOException

readLineIgnoreLeadingSpace

public java.lang.String readLineIgnoreLeadingSpace()
                                            throws java.io.IOException
Read a line from the buffer, throwing away any whitespace characters at the start of the line.

Returns:
The line read, with any initial whitespace characters discarded
Throws:
java.io.IOException
See Also:
readLine()

java.io.IOException

readOrderedKeyValuePairs

public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> readOrderedKeyValuePairs(java.lang.String[] keys)
                                                                          throws java.io.IOException

This reads in a series of lines from a file, each of which is supposed to contain a key-value pair separated by white space. Keys are not case sensitive. The argument to the method contains an array of keys, dictating the order in which key-value pairs are to appear in the file. Each element of the array has a simple grammar:

key → key expression
key → ?key expression

key expression → key name {| key name}

key name → any string not containing white space, ? or |.

Examples: ncols -- the text "ncols" must appear as the key name in the corresponding line in the file. ?ncols -- the text "ncols" may appear as a key name in the corresponding line in the file. ncols|nrows -- the text "ncols" or the test "nrows" must appear as the key name in the corresponding line in the file. ?ncols|nrows|ntables -- the text "ncols", "nrows" or "ntables" may appear as a key name in the corresponding line in the file.

If the last line read in the file was not parsed, this method will read it. It may also leave an unparsed but read line.

Parameters:
keys - An array of keys, as defined using the above grammar.
Returns:
A map of key names to values.
Throws:
java.io.IOException

getKeyMessage

private java.lang.String getKeyMessage(java.lang.String[] keyOptions)
Create a more human readable form of a key by replacing | characters with a comma (the last one with "or").

Parameters:
keyOptions - An array of key options already split from the key at |
Returns:
A phrase describing the list

getKeyMessage

private java.lang.String getKeyMessage(java.lang.String key)
Create a more human readable form of a key by removing ? and replacing | characters with a comma (the last one with "or").

Parameters:
key - The key
Returns:
A phrase describing the key

getKeyMessage

private java.lang.String getKeyMessage(java.lang.String[] keys,
                                       int i)
Create a human-readable form of a series of keys. This series should consist of zero or more optional keys followed by one required key. The absence of a required key is a bug.

Parameters:
keys - The array of keys
i - The position in the array at which to start
Returns:
A phrase describing the series of keys

getKeyOptions

private java.lang.String[] getKeyOptions(java.lang.String key)
Create an array of key options from a key by removing any initial ? and splitting at |.

Parameters:
key - The key
Returns:
An array of key options
